Description: Four fragments from the neck and shoulder of glass vessel, possibly an alabastron or similar closed shape. Clear light blue with opaque white, opaque dark blue and opaque orange(?) trails. Lower part of cylindrical neck, meeting convex shoulder in gentle, obtuse-angled curve. On neck, zigzag pattern of trails in three colours; on shoulder, horizontal trails of dark blue and white. Core-formed and tooled; trails marvered flush, except dark blue trail on shoulder, which is in sunken relief.
Excavator/field collector: Excavated by: Turner Bequest Excavations, Curium
Curator's comments: The LBA date of these fragments is anomalous with the late Cypro-Archaic range of the remainder of the deposit in Tomb 26. The vase may have been brought from an older tomb elsewhere in the area (such as Bamboula) rather than represent re-use of the chamber, as no LBA tombs are known from the vicinity of Site B.
BM Glass The tomb was used more than once, since it also contained BM Glass 337, a fragmentary fusiform alabastron of Mediterranean group 3. Nolte 1968,119, s.n. 36a (described, without reg. no.).
Bibliographic references: Glass / Catalogue of Greek and Roman Glass in the British Museum (20)
Murray, Smith and Walters 1900 / Excavations in Cyprus (p.82, Tomb 26 no. 5)
Condition: White enamel-like surface weathering, largely obscuring the colours.
